issues.description: The template's helper method singFarmSongVerse is declared without an Animal parameter (private void singFarmSongVerse(/*Animal animal*/)), but the problem UML and the solution expect singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). This prevents students from implementing singFarmSong() by calling singFarmSongVerse(animal) for each animal and from using the animal inside the verse (e.g., to print the animal type and call messageOnFeed()). The commented-out parameter in the template is likely an accidental omission rather than an intentional pedagogical gap.
issues.suggested_fix: Restore the Animal parameter in the template method signature so it matches the UML and solution. For example, change the template method to: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... } and inside use animal.getClass().getSimpleName() and animal.messageOnFeed(). Also update singFarmSong() to iterate animals and call singFarmSongVerse(animal). Ensure the template, problem statement (UML) and solution agree on the parameter.

issues.description: Visibility of singFarmSongVerse differs between artifacts: the UML (problem statement) and the template declare the method as private, but the solution implements it as protected. This inconsistency in visibility may confuse students about the intended accessibility of the helper method (private helper vs. potentially overridable/accessible by subclasses or tests).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the visibility consistent across artifacts. Prefer aligning with the UML and template by using private if the method is intended as an internal helper: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). Alternatively, if the helper should be accessible/overridable (for tests or extension), update the template and UML to declare it protected. Ensure all three artifacts use the same visibility.
